@GOP @GOPLeader 32/ But until they do those who would defend our democracy and this beautiful 243-year old experiment should not rest easy.  Removing Trump through impeachment or the ballot box will not be enough. /fin

@GOP @GOPLeader 31/ And so the voters must.  And I know they can.  Because Elijah Cummings is right.  We're better than this.  The American people have too much decency too much pride and too much respect to tolerate those who put loyalty to party over loyalty to country.
@GOP @GOPLeader 30/ The @GOP has - tragically - proven themselves to be incapable of extinguishing the worst from their ranks or of providing cover/support for their best to act with conviction.

@GOP @GOPLeader 29/ Yeats has written the requiem for the GOP in 2020:  "Everywhere the ceremony of innocence is drowned.  The best lack all conviction while the worst are full of passionate intensity."

@GOP @GOPLeader 28/ And it won’t come back until the voters send a resounding message that the party of Trump of Stephen Miller of McConnell and McCarthy has no place in a country committed to the rule of law and democratic government.
@GOP @GOPLeader 27/ So let's face up to an unpleasant but self-evident truth: the party of Eisenhower the party of Reagan the party of George H.W. Bush… it’s gone.

@GOP @GOPLeader 26/ And when so many of the people who have first-hand knowledge from Pompeo to Mulvaney to Bolton to McGahn are refusing to appear under oath we’re well advised to suspect that the crimes against our Constitution go way beyond Trump.

@GOP @GOPLeader 25/ To be clear those are anecdotes.  We still have due process and suspicions are not convictions.  But when the entire @GOP line of questioning is to weaken US institutions and further Russian-sponsored conspiracy theories we’re well advised to ask.

@GOP @GOPLeader 24/ There is no shortage of anecdotal evidence suggesting the latter from Russian money laundering through the NRA to former Rep Sessions' involvement with Lev Parnas to the circumstances that led to the lifting of sanctions against Rusal etc.
@GOP @GOPLeader 23/ Are they just afraid of Trump?  Or are they also somehow complicit in what is clearly a large-scale Russian influence operation?

@GOP @GOPLeader 22/ Now for the harder question: why has only one party been willing to do their job?  Why has the @GOP decided to act as the President's defense counsel rather than as a member of Congress sworn to protect the Constitution?

@GOP @GOPLeader 21/ That's not a trick question. But the answer is easy: we should do our job.  Do oversight.  Demand accountability.  Use every tool in our arsenal up to and including impeachment if necessary.

@GOP @GOPLeader 20/ Not the Democrats not the Republicans.  What should CONGRESS do?  As the co-equal branch with oversight authority.  As 535 members who have taken an oath to defend the Constitution against all enemies foreign AND domestic?
@GOP @GOPLeader 19/ So now let's rise out of the details.  Nothing in the prior thread is especially complicated or insightful.  This is basic stuff.  What should Congress do with that information?
@GOP @GOPLeader 18/ That makes him a useful Russian asset regardless of whether he has explicitly consented to be used in that capacity.

@GOP @GOPLeader 17/ Trump is useful to them.  He does not understand government does not respect our institutions and is instinctively hostile to multi-lateral long-term win-win agreements.  His mere presence in the White House is a threat to the post-WWII order.
@GOP @GOPLeader 16/ Russia has no strategic ability to rise to the level of power or respect that the United States holds.  But they have a strategic interest in bringing us down to their level.

@GOP @GOPLeader 15/ But there are also non-financial reasons that may not even require Trump's intent.  Remember that Russia is no longer a great power.  Their economy is the size of Texas.  Life expectancy is collapsing.  They are totally dependent on oil & gas.
@GOP 14/ And let’s not forget that even @GOPLeader – not that long ago – said that Trump is likely corrupted by the Russians.  https://t.co/3WsMBA2CDD
@GOP 13/ After all Trump’s own son said a “disproportionate” amount of his money comes from Russia. https://t.co/9Tns28dTpM
@GOP 12/ So why was Trump working to advance Russia's interests?   There is of course the obvious financial angle.
@GOP 11/ So we KNOW that Trump withheld Congressionally-authorized aid to Ukraine that put Ukrainians at risk put US troops in Europe at risk and benefited no one except Trump and Russia.
@GOP 10/ So we have Trump Trump's chief of staff and Trump's personally appointed ambassador all agreeing that there was in fact a quid pro quo.  A bribe. Corruption.
@GOP 9/ And Trump himself said that if he were Zelensky after the July 25 call he would have investigated the Bidens.  And then doubled down by saying China should too!  https://t.co/zmTReO8Q0F

@GOP 8/ Gordon Sondland who - having donated $1 million to Trump's campaign and then got appointed Ukraine ambassador - knows first hand about quid pro quos...  said there was a quid pro quo.  https://t.co/xC62sLtPCs
@GOP 7/ But don't take my word for it. Trump Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney said that there was a quid pro quo.  https://t.co/YKjWdvnjXZ
@GOP 6/ That is textbook corruption.  It is also a textbook bribe.  It is also a quid pro quo. These are all synonyms no matter what the President says.
@GOP 5/ The "favor" was to look into Crowdstrike (a Russian-sponsored fully-debunked conspiracy theory) and to dig up dirt on the Bidens.
@GOP 4/ Donald Trump withheld military aid to Ukraine until they "did a favor" for him.  Those are his words in the version of the call transcript that he released. https://t.co/Nf9wqnxZ7w
@GOP 3/ So let's review what we learned:
@GOP 2/ To be sure there are many good members of the @GOP.  But they are silent in this moment and to be silent is to be complicit.
My overwhelming conclusion after the last few weeks' hearings is that the @GOP - in its current incarnation - is a fundamental threat to our democracy.  Thread:

@Jessica05523568 A tax on a coal plant does nothing to enhance your investment thesis as you consider putting a solar panel on your roof.

To he clear we MUST monetize the externality of CO2 emissions and use markets to allocate capital.  But the structure of how we do that matters and the proposal described in that Hill article is a really bad structure.

22) With heavy hearts we move forward.  No member of Congress celebrates this moment.  But yesterday I'm glad to at least report that the majority of us voted not to shirk our responsibility. /fin
21) But we - and by we I mean all of us - cannot allow their obedience to conclude that a partisan vote is bad policy.

20) I am sorry - and in many ways angry - that not a single Republican saw fit to vote in favor of these rules.  Their obedience and deference to the Executive branch is an abdication of their responsibilities.
19) So what happens next?  We wrap up closed sessions as soon as we can and then move into open hearings subject to these rules.  We do so with open minds and no pre-determined verdict.

18) Indeed if we DID require a full vote of the House to approve the agenda of any committee the House would never get anything done.  Every member of Congress knows that.  But some are hoping the public doesn’t.  That is irresponsible.

17) In the same fashion it makes no sense to argue that the Intel Oversight Judiciary Ways & Means Financial Services or Foreign Affairs committees cannot hold hearings subject to their jurisdiction prior to a full vote of the House.
16) For example no one would argue that the Science Committee cannot hold hearings on ocean acidification prior to a full vote of the House.

15) Others have suggested that the prior process required a vote of the house.  That argument is silly and unfounded.  Every committee in Congress has the right to set their own agenda subject to the majoritarian opinion of their members.

14) In the Clinton and Nixon cases impeachment hearings came AFTER the AG's office had led closed hearings to ensure that witnesses could not coordinate their stories.  Barr’s failure to do so and his efforts to distort the Mueller report forced a different process this time.
13) However the approach taken was fully appropriate given the circumstances.
12) Some have suggested that the prior phase should have been open.  That's irrelevant to what we do next.  History is behind us.
11) That's the extent of the logical objections.  That's not to say that there can't be illogical objections of course... so let's examine some of those.
10) (c) Because you think the Congress should not inquire as to whether the President should be impeached under any circumstances
9) (b) Because you are opposed to majoritarian democracies where the actions of a legislative body require the consent of >50% of the members or
8)  (a) Because you want greater protections to the President in this process than has ever been granted in prior processes
7) So it's worth asking the question why someone would vote "no" on yesterday's resolution.  There are only three logically possible reasons:

6) This weird narrative that the minority party deserves greater protection implicitly presumes that the minority party is on trial. No one is making that argument except perhaps for those who doth protest too much.

5) There is a very important point to be noted in that prior table.  The protections afforded by this process are to the President not his political party.  As is appropriate since he is the subject of our inquiry.
4) The rules we passed were not only fair but in some cases more generous to the President than the rules that were passed for the Nixon and Clinton processes. https://t.co/yHnRVdz03j
3) The question we were all asked yesterday was not whether we should move forward but whether we agree to move forward subject to a specific set of rules.

2) On the substance let’s first state the obvious: we did not vote to impeach the President yesterday nor did we vote to initiate an impeachment inquiry nor did we vote on articles of impeachment.  We voted to set the rules for the next (open) phase of the process.
1) First please read the bill. Rather than relying on shoddy journalists or self-interested partisans go to the original source material: https://t.co/1tuX2jh1yM

@sulli1993 Quite agree. Thus "more".  Greenburgh still isn't Scarsdale or Rye.  But yes Westchester County is far from homogenous.
@SethS_D 19/ So here's to public education.  And to maintaining as many of those spaces in society as we can where we can all get "proximate" to one another.    And much love to WHS '89!  /fin

@SethS_D 18/ And not just mine.  My old friends and classmates are now teachers bankers lawyers engineers stay-at-home parents... but more importantly are good people who all marvel at how unique our K-12 experience was in our later lives.  And how formative.

@SethS_D 17/ And yet the diversity of those K-12 schools was - and still is - driven in part by the fact that so many affluent families opted out the better to help get their kids into colleges and towns like mine.

@SethS_D 16/ It certainly has for me.  My college grad school and current hometown were terrific and created opportunities for me I would never trade in... but none were as diverse as the K-12 public schools I started in.
@SethS_D 15/ And that's fine!  We want the best opportunities for our kids.  We want to live & work in places where we are valued and respected.  But that process tends to filter out diversity.

@SethS_D 14/ After we get out of high school no matter how hard we may try our communities tend to self-select for those with more similar values talents and wealth.  Our colleges our places of worship the towns we choose to live in.

@SethS_D 13/ So what does this have to do with public K-12 education?  Because for far too many of us that is the last and only real time in our lives when we are exposed to the full cross-section of our communities.

12/ Meanwhile as @SethS_D showed in his book "Everybody Lies" the best predictor that someone voted for Trump in 2016 was that they lived in an ethically homogeneous community where racist jokes go unchecked.
11/ And as Bryan Stevenson has so eloquently explained "We cannot create justice without getting close to places where injustices prevail... we have to get proximate.”

10/ But here's thing: values and ethics get set young.  Surround yourself with lots of different people and you develop a greater empathy and understanding.  Self-isolate into homogeneous communities and you lose that educational opportunity precisely when it is most impactful.

9/ This isn't new and was well underway when I was there 30 years ago.  Purely on the basis of test results and college placement the district has historically compared unfavorably to many neighboring districts.  So wealthier families opt out.
8/ Not because there are fewer kids but because so many have opted out of the public school system.
7/ When I was in elementary school there were two K-4 schools 2 5-6 middle schools and one high school.  Today it's one K-2 one 3-4 one 5-6 and one high school.

6/ It's still just as diverse if not more.  In part because the community is still diverse and in part because so many affluent largely white families have either moved to neighboring towns or sent their kids to private & parochial schools.
5/ My school district was one of the early districts to desegregate through busing.  See this NYT article from 1972 4 years before I got to 1st grade... https://t.co/V0Oppm1TMF
4/ Now a bit of background.  I grew up in Hartsdale NY.  Suburb of NYC and an unusually diverse part of an otherwise affluent and more homogeneous Westchester county.
3/ And a thanks to the staff and administration at RJ Bailey (my middle school) for giving me the chance to come to speak to current students. https://t.co/esKq66fAYB
2/ First a shout out to everyone at Woodlands High School class of '89 who made it out! https://t.co/G7IxOU3Crl
